pronunciation: AGA'TE, [a and gate.] [Gr. so called, says Pliny, 34, 10, because found near a river of that name in Sicily. So also Solinus and Isidore. But Bochart, with more probability, deduces it from the Punic and Hebrew, and with a different prefix, spotted. The word is used, Genesis 30:32 and 33, to describe the speckled and spotted cattle of Laban and Jacob.]A

definitions.text:
Agate
 On the way; going. obsolete
AG'ATE,

class siliceous, semi-pellucid gems many varieties, consisting quartz-crystal, flint, horn-stone, chalcedony, amethyst, jasper, cornealian, heliotrope, jade, various combinations, variegated dots, zones, filaments, ramifications, arborizations, various figures. Agates seem have been formed by successive layers siliceous earth, on sides cavities which they now fill entirely part.
They are esteemed least valuable precious stones. Even Pliny's time, they were little estimation. They are rocks, form fragments, nodules, small rounded lumps, rarely stalactites. Their colors are various. They are for rings, seals, cups, beads, boxes handles small utensils.
AG'ATE,

An instrument by goldwire drawers, agate middle it.
First occurrence Bible(KJV): Exodus 28:19
